Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the effectiveness of Lysol in killing the new coronavirus by stating that "the label of the popular Lysol already shows that the product kills the coronavirus."
Understate: The claim understates the seriousness and novelty of the new coronavirus by suggesting that it is "nothing new" because Lysol lists "Human Coronavirus" on its label.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support to back up its assertion that the new coronavirus is not new based solely on the presence of "Human Coronavirus" on Lysol's label.
Problematic assumption: The claim makes the problematic assumption that because Lysol and Clorox products list "Human Coronavirus" on their bottles, they already knew about the new coronavirus.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim fails to consider alternative explanations for why Lysol and Clorox products list "Human Coronavirus" on their labels, such as their effectiveness against other strains of the coronavirus that cause the common cold.
